sect2.title: Connecting using Network Manager
sect2.para: Network Manager (&networking;) supports Roaming mode. This allows you to connect to any available wireless network in range.

listitem.para: In the Taskbar click the Network Manager icon.
Select your wireless network from the list.
Enter your Network Key.
Click Connect.
Select the connection and press Properties.
From the Network Name drop down box choose your router. If it is not shown your router may not broadcast its ID. In this case manually enter the ESSID.
Select the Password Type and enter your password.
If your ISP gave you a static IP address then select Static IP Address from the Configuration box.
If your router assigns IP addresses then leave the Configuration as Automatic Configuration (DHCP).
Click OK.

sect1.title: Troubleshooting
sect1.para: This troubleshooting guide is designed to be carried out in order.

listitem.para: Open Device Manager (&device-manager;).
Check to see the hardware is recognised if it is then
If your device is not displayed then there may be a hardware problem. Ensure if it is PCMCIA or PCI that it is inserted correctly.
Open a Terminal (&terminal;) and type the command: sudo lshw -C network
If there is a driver listed then see .
Set up NDISWrapper ().
Many wireless network devices can be turned on or off. Check to see if the device is turned on by opening a Terminal (&terminal;) and type the command: sudo lshw -C network.
If it is turned on then see .

sect2.title: Check for a connection to the router

listitem.para: Open a Terminal (&terminal;) and type the command: iwconfig.
If there is an entry that says ESSID="" then see .
If the ESSID for our router is shown there may be a problem with ACPI support. Boot the kernel with the pci=noacpi option.
Open a Terminal (&terminal;) and type the command: ifconfig.
If there is an IP address shown see .
From the Terminal enter the command: sudo dhclient if_name where if_name is the connection listed earlier.
If you receive a message that says bound to xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx then see
If not then reboot the system.
Open a Terminal (&terminal;) and type the command: ping 82.211.81.158.
Now type the command: ping www.ubuntu.com. If you get a response from the both then see .
Type the command: cat /etc/resolv.conf. If there is no nameserver listed then contact your ISP and find out your primary and secondary domain name servers. Once you have this information see .
IPv6 is supported by default in Ubuntu and can sometimes cause problems.
To disable it, open a Terminal (&terminal;) and type the command: gksudo gedit /etc/modprobe.d/aliases.
Find the line alias net-pf-10 ipv6 and change it to read alias net-pf-10 off.
Reboot Ubuntu.

sect1.title: Using Windows Wireless Drivers
sect1.para: Ubuntu supports a system known as NDISWrapper. This allows you to use a Windows wireless device driver under Ubuntu.

listitem.para: Obtain the Windows Driver for your system and locate the file that ends with .inf.
Install ndisgtk (&synaptic;).
Open ndisgtk (&ndisgtk;).
Select Install new driver.
Choose the location of your Windows .inf file and click Install.
Click OK.

sect2.title: Configuring WPA support.
sect2.para: WiFi Protected Access (WPA) is an based on WEP and provides stronger security.
WPA is integrated with Network Manager. You must also have the wpasupplicant package installed.
If you need to manually configure WPA support, see the Wiki Entry.
